Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Solving Linear Differential in Terms of Special Functions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: Differential equations have numerous applications in science and engineering. In this project, new algorithms will be developed to compute exact solutions of linear differential equations. The project consists of two components, a top-down approach and a bottom-up approach. The bottom-up approach is to develop an algorithm for each particular type of solutions. In contrast, the top-down algorithms are not specific to any particular type of solution, instead, the top-down algorithms aim to reduce an equation to one that is easier to solve. This complements the bottom-up approach in several ways. By reducing to an easier equation, the top-down approach can drastically reduce the computation time it takes to solve the equation. Moreover, the top-down approach also reduces the number of algorithms need to be developed and implemented in the bottom-up approach; only equations that can not be reduced any further need to be treated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
New algorithms were developed to compute exact (closed form) solutions of second order linear differential equations. These algorithms have shown that closed form solutions are far more common than previously thought. For example, the Online Encyclopedia for Integer Sequences contained hundreds of cases where no closed form expression was known for the generating function even though it satisfied a second order linear differential equation. It turned out that these generating functions do have closed form expressions; the algorithms developed during this project can often find them quickly.
The project consisted of a bottom-up approach, covering a large set of cases, and a top-down approach, to reduce equations to cases that have been covered.
The relevance of the top-down approach is that it reduces the number of cases in the bottom-up approach to a much more manageable number. The key result in the top-down approach is an algorithm called 2-descent, developed jointly with Tingting Fang, who is one of the graduate students supported by this grant. The idea in this approach is to search for a change of variables that leaves the equation invariant up to so-called "projective equivalence". If such transformation exists, it can be exploited to reduce the equation to another equation with simpler solutions, with degree reduced a factor 2.
A bottom-up approach was pursued by Vijay Kunwar, another graduate student supported by this grant, and by Raimundas Vidunas, a co-author. It turns out that one can develop a differential solver by finding functions that belong certain pictures called dessins d'enfants. In Kunwar's PhD thesis this is developed further by computing braid actions on so-called near-dessins, then finding the corresponding functions, and implementing the resulting differential solver.

This project supported 11 publications and 4 PhD theses.
